titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women Newspaper and Pamphlet Collection TAM.653
titlestmt.author: Maggie Schreiner

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-20 16:40:26 -0400.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women Newspaper and Pamphlet Collection

physdesc.extent: in 12 record cartons and 1 manuscript box

did.abstract: The Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women were founded in the mid-1960s in Seattle as revolutionary feminist organizations within the socialist movement. The two organizations formally affiliated in 1973. This collection consists of serials and pamphlets collected by the Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women. The subjects represented in the titles and content of the publications are socialism, feminism, lesbian and gay liberation, indigenous organizing, and prisoners' issues, among others. There are a limited number of international titles. The collection is an excellent source of information about the small presses of the revolutionary Left, as well as the history of the movements reflected in, and publishing, the newspapers and pamphlets.
did.physloc: Materials are located onsite at the Tamiment Library.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English, with a small number of materials in Spanish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Helen Gilbert on behalf of Radical Women and the Freedom Socialist Party in 2014. The accession number associated with this gift is 2014.138.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into three series. The first two series are arranged in alphabetical order by title; Series III is arranged in alphabetical order by subject.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Freedom Socialist Party (FSP) was founded in Seattle, Washington in 1966 after a split in the U.S. Socialist Workers Party. Radical Women was created the following year by FSP founder Clara Fraser, her friend Gloria Martin, and activists from Students for a Democratic Society. Both organizations were established in the political contexts of international liberation struggles, the civil rights movement, and the Vietnam War. The political programs of these organizations, heavily influenced by Trotskyism, attempt to situate racial justice, women's, and gay liberation movements within the Marxist framework. Therefore, the FSP and Radical Women look to these historically oppressed groups to provide revolutionary leadership. Radical Women provides trainings for women to assume leadership roles in social justice movements. Both organizations have been active in the anti-Vietnam war movement, union organizing, indigenous struggles and LGBTQ issues. The FSP and Radical Women formally affiliated in 1973.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women Newspaper and Pamphlet Collection; TAM 653; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of acquistion, most of the materials were arranged loosely by title. During processing, all materials were placed in archival boxes and folders and arranged into alphabetical order by title of the serial or pamphlet. A small grouping of subject files was present within the collection (mixed into the alphabetical run of titles). These folders containing subject files were separated and placed in Series III. Folder titles in Series III are original to the FSP/Radical Women, except those in square brackets, which have been supplied by the archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of newspapers and pamphlets collected by the Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women. The publications span the 1930s to the 2000s, with the bulk from the 1970s to the early 1980s. The collection includes over 300 titles, from primarily American publishers, with a small number of international titles. The serials often only include one or two issues from each title. This collection is particularly strong in the following subject areas: socialism, feminism, gay liberation, civil rights, indigenous organizing and prisoners' issues. A small number of pamphlets address similar topics, with an additional focus on international issues, including Angola, Ireland and South Africa. The collection also includes subject files, which are comprised of newspapers and pamphlets that were arranged topically by the Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women. The collection is an excellent source of information about the small presses of the revolutionary Left, as well as the history of the movements reflected in, and publishing, the newspapers and pamphlets.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Duplicate issues were removed from the collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Because of the assembled nature of this collection, copyright status varies across the collection. Copyright is assumed to be held by the original creator of individual items in the collection; these items are expected to pass into the public domain 120 years after their creation. The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from this collection.

controlaccess.corpname: Communist Party of the United States of America

did.unittitle: Series I: Serials by Title

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series represents the bulk of the collection, and includes over 300 different titles published by a large array of organizations. Many titles only include one or two issues, while a few have more complete runs. Titles with a significant number of issues include The Militant (Militant Publishing Company, Socialist Workers Party), The Movement (Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee and Students for a Democratic Society), The Newsletter (Socialist Labor League), Seattle Gay News (Gay Community Center), and Sojourner (Sojourner Feminist Institute). Publishers with multiple titles include the International Defence and Aid Fund for Southern Africa, the National Lawyers Guild, the United Secretariat of the Fourth International, the National Organization for Women, a variety of Leonard Peltier support groups, and others. Publishers are based both in the U.S. and internationally, and the cities of Seattle, New York, and Boston are particularly well represented. Major subjects in this series include socialism, Trotskyism and Marxism, civil rights, the early feminist and lesbian movements, gay liberation, indigenous organizing, and prisoners' issues.

Series II: Pamphlets by Title

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series includes a small number of pamphlets published by a variety of organizations, including the Liberation Support Movement Information Center, Pathfinder Press (Socialist Workers Party), Peoples Democracy and the Communist Party. Subjects addressed include socialism, Trotskyism and revolutionary organizing, civil rights, gay liberation, and others. International issues in countries including Angola, Ireland and South Africa are included. There are also a small number of directories and U.S. government publications.

Series III: Subject Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains subject files, which are comprised of newspapers and pamphlets that were arranged topically by the Freedom Socialist Party and Radical Women. Newspaper titles, and even individual issues, included in Series I may also be found in this series. The subjects included in Series III are representative of the collection as a whole, with additional emphasis on international issues.
